video.title: PERN Stack Course - Build a Yelp clone (Postgres, Express, React, Node.js)
video.description:
Learn the PERN stack by building a Yelp clone. The PERN stack includes PostgreSQL, Express, React, and Node. You will learn all the basics including installation, creating databases/tables, making queries, adding entries, establishing relationship between tables, SQL joins, and more. 

💻 Code - https://github.com/Sanjeev-Thiyagarajan/PERN-STACK-YELP-CLONE

🎥 Course developed by Sanjeev Thiyagarajan. Check out his YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC2sYgV-NV6S5_-pqLGChoNQ?sub_confirmation=1

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️ 
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro 
⌨️ (0:04:11) PERN Stack Intro 
⌨️ (0:07:58) Postgres Windows Install 
⌨️ (0:16:35) Postgres Mac install 
⌨️ (0:29:13) Postgres Documentation 
⌨️ (0:30:29) PSQL Basics 
⌨️ (0:37:04) SQL Tables 
⌨️ (0:38:53) Create Table 
⌨️ (0:45:55) Modify Tables 
⌨️ (0:48:28) Delete Databases 
⌨️ (0:50:58) Yelp Project Database 
⌨️ (1:09:57) Node Setup 
⌨️ (1:12:45) Express Setup 
⌨️ (1:15:57) Environment Variables 
⌨️ (1:19:40) First Express Route 
⌨️ (1:29:27) Restful API Convention 
⌨️ (1:32:33) Configure all routes 
⌨️ (1:42:34) Express Middleware 
⌨️ (1:54:13) Finishing Up Routes 
⌨️ (2:03:10) Connect Express and Postgres 
⌨️ (2:14:20) Get all Restaurants Route 
⌨️ (2:18:25) Gone one Restaurant Route 
⌨️ (2:28:23) Create a Restaurant Route 
⌨️ (2:35:28) Update A Restaurant Route 
⌨️ (2:43:07) Delete A Restaurant Route 
⌨️ (2:46:28) React Setup 
⌨️ (2:52:52) React Router Setup 
⌨️ (3:02:03) HomePage Layout 
⌨️ (3:14:24) React Context API 
⌨️ (3:20:17) Fetching Data 
⌨️ (3:36:12) Rendering Restaurants 
⌨️ (3:41:48) Adding Restaurants 
⌨️ (3:56:26) Deleting Restaurants 
⌨️ (4:03:05) Updating Restaurants 
⌨️ (4:26:18) Detail Page 
⌨️ (4:38:06) Reviews Intro 
⌨️ (4:39:46) Reviews Postgres Table 
⌨️ (4:55:20) Star Rating Component 
⌨️ (5:02:49) Reviews Component Layout 
⌨️ (5:08:18) Add Review 
⌨️ (5:29:06) Add Review Express Route 
⌨️ (5:37:43) Add Review React Component 
⌨️ (5:48:04) Postgres Aggregate Functions 
⌨️ (5:57:26) SQL Joins and Wrapping up App


--


Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org


Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Tabish Javed
topLevelComment.text:
if your content does not get displayed around 2:57:48, do this <Router>
        <Routes>
          <Route path="/" element={<Home/>}/>
          <Route path="/restaurants/:id/update" element={<UpdatePage/>} />
          <Route path="/restaurants/:id" element={<RestaurantDetailPage/>}/>
        </Routes>
      </Router>

replies.text: but you need to add i little time delay between navigate from home page back to the details page, to give the app enough time to actually run the useEffect hook and get a response back to load the new review.

topLevelComment.author: Jairo Espinel

topLevelComment.author: Travis
topLevelComment.text: First off, great course. I'm learning a ton. Second, if anyone is bumping into issues getting routes to load (i.e. around the "Router Setup" section starting at 2:52:52), be aware of your capitalization. I had trouble where none of the text in my home, details, etc routes would show. Turns out that I had stuff like element={<home />} in my route instead of element={<Home />}. Did some searching and came to a stack overflow post that basically said that React treats lowercase element names as HTML and uppercased element names as React components.

topLevelComment.author: ThatGuy

topLevelComment.author: Arif Waqas
topLevelComment.text: For those who do not know about context. The context api in react is used when you wish brodcast certain props through all the levels of the tree without having to manually pass them down as props at each and every juncture so theoretically wherever (component) you wrap your provider that is associated to that context, whatever props you are associating with that context will be available to all the children components of that component (around which you wrapped that provider)

topLevelComment.author: Schmutz06
topLevelComment.text:
I'm working through this. Will I be able to get something working online using this, or is 'deployment' (I hear it said often) another big tutorial?

For reference I recently started looking at coding/development or whatever this 'is' with no previous experience this year.

within 1 hour - I first learned what an IDE is.
After two days I created a gui in python that goes to a website and searches for something.
After a month - first holy grail - I followed a tutorial to write a java app in 'Eclipse' that manipulated a online database. I also managed to connect to Postgres DB using psql to verify the updates worked. That was exciting progress.

After 1.5 months (now) - I have just came across the term 'PERN Stack'. 

Now if day 1, I was sent to this tutorial, with none of the previous context, I believe I'd have gotten off to a speedier start. 'PERN Stack' was the magic word(s) I was looking for.

Honestly, even if it seems crazy to experienced devs, as a newbie I would love to make a basic database with one table; ID, name. I want to display it on a living breathing website. Then I want to create front end buttons to add/delete rows from it. I really want to sprint toward this goal, with my eyes closed. Just for context, for absolute context. I don't want to know the details and why it works, but I want to get this far in the fastest possible way. THEN I want to go back and invest 1000+ hours or however long it takes to learn.

topLevelComment.author: Doctor Web
topLevelComment.text:
Tips: to display the new reviews after creating them, 
1-in the Review component instead of refreshing the page or double redirect, we could create a new useState called [newReview, setnewReview] = useState(false).
2- pass newReview as a dependency of the useEffect
2- pass both newReview and setNewReview to the AddReview component as props
3- in the AddReview component call setReview(!newReview) in the handleSubmit function.

it gonna display the new review after adding.

replies.author: iamharald
replies.text: An even better way is to do have this state in RestaurantDetailPage and define a function that toggles it there, then pass this function as a callback to AddReview.

topLevelComment.author: Pearls & Swine
topLevelComment.text:
I loved this tutorial and am thankful for it, but this 6-hour video could have been reduced to 3-4 hours if you didn't make so many errors.  It seemed like every 5-10 minutes you crashed the app and a few minutes were dedicated to trying to find it, and it almost always was from a syntax error.  The others were from writing code to show "one way of doing it", and then deleting it to show "another way".  


The biggest issue was still the constant debugging and how much time was spent on it.  Still good video!

Some basic stuff was explained quite thorougly and other stuff was just expected. However if you would have explained everything I guess you would have needed at least twice the time. 

Just want to let you know: There is a bug at the end. The average ratings on the RestaurantList component don't match up with the average ratings on the detail page. 

Thanks again for this really awesome job!!

topLevelComment.author: Joanis Polo
topLevelComment.text: The little space that occurs on the dropdown menu is due to the bootstrap class ' my-1 '. Just remove it and the space will be gone. It stands for margin top and bottom.

topLevelComment.author: Tom R
topLevelComment.text: I used window.location = location.pathname and it worked for refreshing the add review instead of adding history.push

topLevelComment.author: Miru Pie
topLevelComment.text:
Noob here.  Is there a reason why you recommend installing create react app globally?  The official website documentation suggests deleting create-react-app globally and to run NPX instead so I'm not sure which way is better.  All i know is create-react-app seems really bloated and it takes my computer forever to delete a create-react-app folder.

Also at 3:08:50, the weird spacing is due to "my-1"  in the bootstrap class.  That added the extra margin on top/bottom.

topLevelComment.author: Ahmed Zubir
topLevelComment.text:
how i can solve psql error
psql: error: could not connect to server: Connection refused (0x0000274D/10061)
        Is the server running on host "localhost" (::1) and accepting
        TCP/IP connections on port 5432?
could not connect to server: Connection refused (0x0000274D/10061)
        Is the server running on host "localhost" (127.0.0.1) and accepting
        TCP/IP connections on port 5432?

topLevelComment.author: Sailing Lilith
topLevelComment.text: At 3:08:42  you mention the alignment of the price range drop down. This is because you added the  <select className="custom-select my-1 mr-sm-2"> and my-1 adds a top and bottom margin, and mr adds margin right. The other elements in the row are not similarly adjusted. If you declare <select className="custom-select"> then it render perfectly.

topLevelComment.author: Mike DiMuro
topLevelComment.text: I can't seem to delete a restaurant if it has reviews. Looks like PG won't allow it because of the foreign key dependency. Is there something I need to add to the delete query to cascade down to remove the reviews as well? Similar to the join.

topLevelComment.author: Noah Kanyo
topLevelComment.text: To help out with the problem at 5:46:26 -> this is where a state management library like redux comes in handy to update the state application wide and refresh the page, but I totally understand why that's not part of your video. Thanks for the amazing content :)

topLevelComment.author: htky
topLevelComment.text:
While this is a great informative tutorial for beginners, there are many left out subjects, like form validation, error handling, discarding reviews when deleting a restaurant, possibly an auth system too.
Anyway, thank you! I learned quite a lot from this

topLevelComment.author: Louis Raymond
topLevelComment.text:
The \? uses less program to make it easier to navigate around. Thankfully, less program supports so many vim-like commands like '/' and '?' to look (search) forward and backwards respectively. You can find more help of the less commands by pressing 'h' on your keyboard. 

Though, I can understand that programming tools are often made using some UNIX styled tools which regular Windows user might not know. Great tutorial nonetheless!

topLevelComment.author: Григорий С
topLevelComment.text: Thank you for the lesson. But you forgot to tell about form validation, cuz now it is possible to create empty restaurant and empty review. Because empty string and NOT NULL are not the same constraints. Better use CHECK(length(name) > 0). Also you forgot about ON DELETE CASCADE, in current version you cant delete restaurants, which already have reviews.

replies.author: Raul Piva Burigo
replies.text:
I used context too, but in a different way...
I created a new state and a function that sets this state in my ContextProvider... than I called that state within my RestaurantDetail component and added this state to my useEffect variables lists
so when a review is added, that context function is called and changes the state, forcing the useEffect to run

He will not abandoned those in distress but bless the ones who mourn! Accept God and Gods son Jesus Christ by believing in him Christ Jesus whom is our Lord and our Savior, and king of kings, and Lord of Lords and you shall receive the gift of eternal life and be renewed with that of the abundance in that of the Holy Spirit now and forevermore! Have a wonderful day/night everybody, and farewell!(Share the message around the world!)....,........
